elements.content: Using a novel hemirigid multitopic ligand, benzene-1,2,3-triyldioxy-triacetic acid (H3L), five metal(II) complexes formulated as Cd3L2(H2O)3·H2O (1), Zn(L)(BPPA) 1/2 ·(HBPPA) (BPPA = N,N′-bis-(4-pyridyl)phthalamide) (2), M(HL)(phen)(H2O)2·H2O (phen = phenanthroline) (M = Zn (3) and Co (4)) and Cd(HL)(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)·5H2O (2,2′-bpy = 2,2′-bipyridine) (5) have been hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 features a 2-nodal (4, 5)-connected three-dimensional (3D) LIBNIU net with a (3.42.5.6.7)(32.43.5.62.7.8) topology. Complex 2 exhibits a 2-nodal (3, 4)-connected two-dimensional (2D) framework with a novel (4.7.8)(4.74.8) topology, in which the μ2-BPPA is self-penetrated into a cage of the 2D layer constructed by neighboring six Zn(II) ions and six L3–. Complexes 3 and 4 are isostructural, and they are mononuclear Zn(II) and Co(II) complexes, respectively, in which strong intramolecular π–π stacking interactions are observed between phen and the phenyl ring of HL2–. Complex 5 is a mononuclear Cd(II) complex, which is assembled into 3D supramolecular architecture via strong intermolecular π–π stacking interactions and H bonds. L3– or HL2– displays different coordination modes in the five complexes. Complexes 1–3 and 5 show different UV absorptions, emission spectra, and photoluminescence lifetimes.

Complex 1 features a 2-nodal (4, 5)-connected three-dimensional (3D) LIBNIU net with a (3.42.5.6.7)(32.43.5.62.7.8) topology. Complexes 3 and 4 are isostructural, and they are mononuclear Zn(II) and Co(II) complexes, respectively, in which strong intramolecular π-π stacking interactions are observed between phen and the phenyl ring of HL2-. elements.content: Over the past two decades, the crystal engineering of metal complexes has provoked unparalleled attention and imagination within coordination chemistry based on assembly of judiciously chosen metal ions (joints) and multifunctional organic ligands (struts). Much effort has been devoted to controlling the structures of metal complexes because their intriguing properties and potential applications are strongly dependent on their structures. Despite some recent advancement, the ability to predict and control supramolecular assembly remains a longstanding challenge, and much more elaborate and systematic work is required to comprehend the inter- and intramolecular forces that determine the fashions of molecular structure and crystal packing in the solid state.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past two decades, the crystal engineering of metal complexes has provoked unparalleled attention and imagination within coordination chemistry based on assembly of judiciously chosen metal ions (joints) and multifunctional organic ligands (struts). Much effort has been devoted to controlling the structures of metal complexes because their intriguing properties and potential applications are strongly dependent on their structures. Despite some recent advancement, the ability to predict and control supramolecular assembly remains a longstanding challenge, and much more elaborate and systematic work is required to comprehend the inter- and intramolecular forces that determine the fashions of molecular structure and crystal packing in the solid state.

elements.content: As a relatively new class of crystalline materials, metal complexes have potential in a myriad of applications, including gas storage, chemical separation, heterogeneous catalysis, and optical, electronic, and magnetic materials. Nowadays, much effort has been devoted to developing new photoluminescence materials based on metal complexes in view of potential applications as photoactive materials.
elements.clean_text: As a relatively new class of crystalline materials, metal complexes have potential in a myriad of applications, including gas storage, chemical separation, heterogeneous catalysis, and optical, electronic, and magnetic materials. Nowadays, much effort has been devoted to developing new photoluminescence materials based on metal complexes in view of potential applications as photoactive materials.

elements.content: In this regard, our recent study has been mainly focused on the synthesis and characterization of new metal complexes, which show rich structural features and encouraging photoluminescence properties. As an extension of our work, herein, we synthesized a novel hemirigid multitopic ligand, benzene-1,2,3-triyldioxy-triacetic acid (H3L), in which the rigid phenyl ring and flexible −O–CH2– coexist (Scheme a). H3L is chosen based on the following considerations: (1) The hemirigid carboxylate linker possesses limited freedom of rotation, which is expected to decrease influence factors of structures. Herein, we aim to illustrate the influence of metal(II) ions and N donors on the coordination modes of H3L. (2) The rigid phenyl ring in the structure of H3L can absorb UV radiations, so the H3L-based metal complexes might behave as photoactive material upon photoexcitation.

elements.content: In the present work, based on H3L and three coligands, N,N′-bis-(4-pyridyl)phthalamide (BPPA), phenanthroline (phen), and 2,2′-bipyridine (2,2′-bpy) (Scheme ), by changing metal(II) ions, we synthesized five metal(II) complexes: Cd3L2(H2O)3·H2O (1), Zn(L)(BPPA) 1/2 ·(HBPPA) (2), M(HL)(phen)(H2O)2·H2O (M = Zn (3) and Co (4)) and Cd(HL)(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)·5H2O (5). In the five complexes, L3– or HL2– possesses different coordination modes. The UV–vis absorption, emission spectra, and photoluminescence lifetimes of the five complexes have been investigated.

elements.content: All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. 1H spectra were recorded on a Bruker 400 MHz apparatus with tetramethylsilane (TMS) as the internal standard. C, H, and N elemental analyses were performed on an Elementar Vario MICRO E III analyzer. IR spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a PerkinElmer spectrometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a RIGAKU DMAX2500PC diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. UV–vis spectra were measured on a HITACHI U-4100 UV–vis spectrophotometer. Solid-state photoluminescence spectra of all the compounds were measured at room temperature on an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer equipped with an Edinburgh Xe900 xenon arc lamp as the exciting light source. The photoluminescence lifetime was conducted on an Edinburgh Lifespec fluorescence spectrometer equipped with a 372 nm laser as the exciting light source.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Considerations

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. 1H spectra were recorded on a Bruker 400 MHz apparatus with tetramethylsilane (TMS) as the internal standard. C, H, and N elemental analyses were performed on an Elementar Vario MICRO E III analyzer. IR spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a PerkinElmer spectrometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a RIGAKU DMAX2500PC diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. UV-vis spectra were measured on a HITACHI U-4100 UV-vis spectrophotometer. Solid-state photoluminescence spectra of all the compounds were measured at room temperature on an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer equipped with an Edinburgh Xe900 xenon arc lamp as the exciting light source. The photoluminescence lifetime was conducted on an Edinburgh Lifespec fluorescence spectrometer equipped with a 372 nm laser as the exciting light source.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray data for complexes 1–5 were collected on an Oxford XCalibur Eos diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Ka (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature. Empirical absorption correction was applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 using SHELXTL-97 software. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All of the hydrogen atoms were placed in the calculated positions. The crystal data and structure refinements for complexes 1–5 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles for complexes 1–5 are listed in Table S1 in the . Further details are provided in the . The CCDC reference numbers are as follows: for complex 1, for complex 2, for complex 3, for complex 4, and for complex 5.

Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c, and its asymmetric unit contains one and a half Cd(II), one L3–, one and a half coordinated water molecules, and half of an uncoordinated water molecule. One carboxylate group from L3– is disordered over two locations (C5 and C5′, O7 and O7′, O8 and O8′), one carboxylate O atom is disordered over two locations (O5 and O5′), and one O atom from a coordinated water molecule is disordered over two locations (O11 and O11′). Each site of them is half-occupied. Another O atom from a coordinated water is disordered over two locations (O10 and O10′), and each site of them has 25% occupancy. Cd(1) is seven-coordinated by five O atoms of five carboxylate groups from four L3– and two O atoms of two ether bonds from one L3– in a pentagonal-bipyramidal coordination geometry [Cd–O 2.195(1)–2.578(2) Å] (Figure a and Table S1, ). Each Cd(1) links with four L3–; thus, Cd(1) can be defined as a 4-connected node. Cd(2) sits on the inversion center, and it exhibits an octahedral coordination environment supplied by four oxygen atoms of two carboxylate groups from two L3– and two aqua ligands [Cd–O 2.165(9)–2.508(3)Å] (Figure a and Table S1, ). Due to the disorder, the occupancy factor of Cd(2) is 0.5, and its second site is calculated from the first position via the inversion operation. Each Cd(2) is linked with two L3– ligands, and Cd(2) acts as a 2-connected linker.

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of Cd3L2(H2O)3⋅H2O (1)

Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c, and its asymmetric unit contains one and a half Cd(II), one L3-, one and a half coordinated water molecules, and half of an uncoordinated water molecule. One carboxylate group from L3- is disordered over two locations (C5 and C5', O7 and O7', O8 and O8'), one carboxylate O atom is disordered over two locations (O5 and O5'), and one O atom from a coordinated water molecule is disordered over two locations (O11 and O11'). Each site of them is half-occupied. Another O atom from a coordinated water is disordered over two locations (O10 and O10'), and each site of them has 25% occupancy. Cd(1) is seven-coordinated by five O atoms of five carboxylate groups from four L3- and two O atoms of two ether bonds from one L3- in a pentagonal-bipyramidal coordination geometry [Cd-O 2.195(1)-2.578(2) Å] (Figure a and Table S1, ). Each Cd(1) links with four L3-; thus, Cd(1) can be defined as a 4-connected node. Cd(2) sits on the inversion center, and it exhibits an octahedral coordination environment supplied by four oxygen atoms of two carboxylate groups from two L3- and two aqua ligands [Cd-O 2.165(9)-2.508(3)Å] (Figure a and Table S1, ). Due to the disorder, the occupancy factor of Cd(2) is 0.5, and its second site is calculated from the first position via the inversion operation. Each Cd(2) is linked with two L3- ligands, and Cd(2) acts as a 2-connected linker.

elements.content: In complex 1, H3L is completely deprotonated, and L3– exhibits a pentadentate coordination fashion, in which one carboxylate group links three Cd(II) centers via a bidentate/bridging coordination mode, one carboxylate group chelates with one Cd(II) center, and the third carboxylate group adopts a chelating/bridging coordination mode connecting one of the above Cd(II) ion and another Cd(II) ion. The O atoms of two ether bonds from L3– also participate in the coordination with one of the Cd(II) centers (Scheme a and Figure a). Different Cd(II) ions are linked by μ2-O and carboxylate bridges to give one-dimensional (1D) chain with Cd(1)···Cd(1A), Cd(2)···Cd(1A), and Cd(1)···Cd(2) separations of 3.836, 4.413, and 4.546 Å, respectively (atom with additional label A refers to the symmetry operation: 1 – x, y, 1/2 – z). Different chains are further connected by the −C6H3– moieties of L3– ligands into three-dimensional (3D) architecture (Figure a,b). As shown in Scheme a, each L3– links with four 4-connected Cd(1) and one 2-connected Cd(2) center. As the 2-connected Cd(2) ion is not counted as a node topologically, two L3– bridged by the 2-connected Cd(2) can be considered to be linked directly from the view of topology. Thus, each L3– is regarded to be connected with four Cd(1) and one L3–, and it can be defined as a 5-connected node. Topological analysis using TOPOS software indicates complex 1 exhibits a 2-nodal (4, 5)-connected 3D LIBNIU net with a (3.42.5.6.7)(32.43.5.62.7.8) topology (Figure c).

elements.content: According to the concept of rod secondary building unit (SBU), the rod SBU consists of {CdO6} octahedra and edge-sharing {CdO7} polyhedra along the c axis (Figure b,c); thus, the complex possesses the symmetry of translation along the c axis (Figure b). Each rod is parallel (Figure b) and connected to four neighboring rods by the phenyl moieties of the L3– linkers (Figure c), and the two-fold axis is found along the b axis in the structure (Figure b). As described above, Cd(2) lies on an inversion center. No other symmetry is found in the parallel packing of the rod SBUs, indicating the topology of complex 1 is complicated compared with the topologies of the 3D frameworks based on rod SBUs reported in ref .

elements.content: Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c with one crystallographically independent Zn(II), one L3–, a half coordinated BPPA, and one uncoordinated monoprotonated HBPPA in the asymmetric unit. Zn(1) is four-coordinated by three oxygen atoms of three carboxylate groups from three L3– and one nitrogen atom from one BPPA to give a slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry [Zn–O 1.9189(16)–1.9706(17) Å, Zn–N 2.0289(18) Å] (Figure a and Table S1, ). In complex 2, the crystallographically independent L3– is completely deprotonated linking three Zn(II) centers with each of its three carboxylate group adopting a monodentate bridging coordination mode (Scheme b). In complex 2, each L3– connects to three Cd(II) centers, and it can be considered as a 3-connected node. Two Zn(II) ions are linked by the BPPA ligand; thus, BPPA can be defined as a 2-connected node and is not counted as a node topologically. Each Zn(II) ion is linked with three L3– and one BPPA, and it can be regarded as a 4-connected node. Topological analysis using TOPOS software indicates complex 2 exhibits a 2-nodal (3, 4)-connected two-dimensional (2D) framework with a novel (4.7.8)(4.74.8) topology (Figure b).

Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c with one crystallographically independent Zn(II), one L3-, a half coordinated BPPA, and one uncoordinated monoprotonated HBPPA in the asymmetric unit. Zn(1) is four-coordinated by three oxygen atoms of three carboxylate groups from three L3- and one nitrogen atom from one BPPA to give a slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry [Zn-O 1.9189(16)-1.9706(17) Å, Zn-N 2.0289(18) Å] (Figure a and Table S1, ). In complex 2, the crystallographically independent L3- is completely deprotonated linking three Zn(II) centers with each of its three carboxylate group adopting a monodentate bridging coordination mode (Scheme b). In complex 2, each L3- connects to three Cd(II) centers, and it can be considered as a 3-connected node. Two Zn(II) ions are linked by the BPPA ligand; thus, BPPA can be defined as a 2-connected node and is not counted as a node topologically. Each Zn(II) ion is linked with three L3- and one BPPA, and it can be regarded as a 4-connected node. elements.content: Another interesting feature of the 2D framework is self-penetration, which is observed. As shown in Figure c,d, μ2-BPPA shows a trans-conformation (Scheme b), and it is penetrated into a cage constructed by the neighboring six Zn(II) ions and six L3–. The dihedral angles between the phenyl ring and the two pyridine rings of trans-BPPA are 39.5°, and the dihedral angle between the two pyridine rings is 0°, indicating μ2-BPPA is almost a planar molecule. Strong hydrogen bonds are observed between the interpenetrated BPPA and the cage. For example, H2–N2: 0.86 Å; H2···O10A: 2.037 Å; N2···O10A: 2.872 Å; ∠N2–H2···O10A: 163.7°; (atom with additional label A refers to the symmetry operation: x, −y + 1/2, z – 1/2).

elements.content: When phen was used instead of BPPA in the synthesis of complex 2, we synthesized complex 3. Complexes 3 and 4 are isostructural except for different metal(II) ions (Table ). Therefore, we will describe the structure of Zn complex 3 in comparison with that of Co complex 4. Complexes 3 and 4 both crystallize in the triclinic space group P1̅. In complex 3, the asymmetric unit contains one Zn(II), one HL2–, one phen, two coordinated water, and one uncoordinated water. The crystallographically independent Zn(1) displays a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry, defined by two N atoms from phen, one oxygen atom from the aqua ligand, and one oxygen from H2L2– in the equatorial positions, one oxygen atom from the aqua ligand and one oxygen atom from the ether bond from H2L2– in the apical positions [Zn–O 2.009(2)–2.3387(19) Å, Zn–N 2.139(3)–2.140(2) Å] (Figure a and Table S1, ). In complex 4, the Co–O and Co–N bond lengths are in the ranges of 2.0123(11)–2.2482(10) and 2.119(3)–2.133(3) Å, respectively, (Table S1, ). In complexes 3 and 4, the crystallographically independent HL2– is partially deprotonated linking one metal(II) center via one monodentate carboxylate oxygen atom and one oxygen atom from the ether bond, leaving the other two carboxylate groups uncoordinated (Figure a and Scheme c). Complex 3 is a mononuclear Zn(II) complex, in which a strong intramolecular π–π stacking interaction is observed between phen and the phenyl ring of HL2– (Figure a). Their centroid–centroid and perpendicular distances are 4.245 and 3.663 Å, respectively. In Co complex 4, the distances are 4.309 and 3.676 Å, respectively.

elements.content: In the presence of a chelating coligand with smaller size, 2,2′-bpy, complex 5 is given, and it crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ with one Cd(II), one HL2–, one 2,2′-bpy, one coordinated water, and five uncoordinated water molecules in the asymmetric unit. elements.content: The XRD powder patterns of complexes 1–5 are shown in Figure S1 in the . All the peaks of the five compounds can be indexed to their respective simulated XRD powder patterns, indicating each of the five compounds is pure phase. The UV–vis absorption spectra of the free organic ligands and complexes 1–5 at room temperature are shown in Figure S2 of the . As shown in Figure S2 of the , the free ligand H3L exhibits strong absorption in the range 240–800 nm with two intense peaks at approximately 268 and 305 nm and a shoulder peak at approximately 470 nm, which may be ascribed to the n−π* or π–π* transitions. BPPA shows an absorption peak at 300 nm in the range 240–500 nm. The absorption band of phen extends from 240 to 450 nm with two peaks at 253 and 332 nm. As for 2,2′-bpy, it shows an intense absorption peak at 267 nm, a shoulder peak at 310 nm, and a weak peak at 540 nm in the range 240–700 nm (Figure S2, ).
elements.clean_text:
UV-Vis Absorption Spectra

The XRD powder patterns of complexes 1-5 are shown in Figure S1 in the . All the peaks of the five compounds can be indexed to their respective simulated XRD powder patterns, indicating each of the five compounds is pure phase. The UV-vis absorption spectra of the free organic ligands and complexes 1-5 at room temperature are shown in Figure S2 of the . As shown in Figure S2 of the , the free ligand H3L exhibits strong absorption in the range 240-800 nm with two intense peaks at approximately 268 and 305 nm and a shoulder peak at approximately 470 nm, which may be ascribed to the n-π* or π-π* transitions. BPPA shows an absorption peak at 300 nm in the range 240-500 nm. The absorption band of phen extends from 240 to 450 nm with two peaks at 253 and 332 nm. As for 2,2'-bpy, it shows an intense absorption peak at 267 nm, a shoulder peak at 310 nm, and a weak peak at 540 nm in the range 240-700 nm (Figure S2, ).

elements.content: Complex 1 displays absorption in the range 240–800 nm with a peak at 269 nm (Figure S2, ), which is different from those of H3L, indicating it may be ascribed to the intraligand (ILCT) transition or the metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) transition. Complexes 2 and 3 exhibit absorption peaks at 290 and 298 nm in the range 240–800 nm, respectively (Figure S2, ). Complex 4 shows a weak absorption band in the similar range with two peaks at 308 and 542 nm, and complex 5 exhibits an absorption peak at 311 nm (Figure S2, ). The absorption peaks for complexes 2–5 in the range 240–400 nm are different from those of the free ligands, indicating they may be ascribed to the ILCT transition, ligand-to-ligand change-transfer (LLCT) transition, or ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) transition. The absorption in the region 400–800 nm for complex 4 may ascribe to the visible d–d transition.

elements.content: The photoluminescence properties of complexes 1–5 together with the free ligands were studied in the solid state at room temperature. The emission spectra of the complexes and the free organic ligands are depicted in Figure S3 of the . The fluorescence lifetimes, τ, of the free organic ligands and the complexes are investigated in the solid state at room temperature, and the curves of the fluorescence decay of them are illustrated in Figure S4 of the .
elements.clean_text:
Emission Spectra and Photoluminescence Lifetimes

The photoluminescence properties of complexes 1-5 together with the free ligands were studied in the solid state at room temperature. The emission spectra of the complexes and the free organic ligands are depicted in Figure S3 of the . The fluorescence lifetimes, τ, of the free organic ligands and the complexes are investigated in the solid state at room temperature, and the curves of the fluorescence decay of them are illustrated in Figure S4 of the .

elements.content: As shown in Figure S3 of the , H3L displays weak emission peaks at 427 and 467 nm when excitated at 364 nm. BPPA shows weak emission with two emission peaks at 467 and 501 nm in the range 400–700 nm (λex = 395 nm). Phen exhibits a very intense emission band at 435 nm (λex = 376 nm). 2,2′-Bpy shows an intense emission band at 408 nm (λex = 380 nm). The emissions of the organic ligands may be ascribed to the π* → n or π → π* transitions.

BPPA shows weak emission with two emission peaks at 467 and 501 nm in the range 400-700 nm (λex = 395 nm). Phen exhibits a very intense emission band at 435 nm (λex = 376 nm). 2,2'-Bpy shows an intense emission band at 408 nm (λex = 380 nm). The emissions of the organic ligands may be ascribed to the π* → n or π → π* transitions.

elements.content: As shown in Figure S4 of the , the process of fluorescence decay for H3L, BPPA, phen, and 2,2′-bpy all follows a single exponential decay law, giving luminescence lifetimes of 0.728, 1.545, 4.351, and 1.829 ns, respectively. Free phen shows longer photoluminescence lifetime (4.351 ns) and stronger emission intensity than those of the other organic ligands, which is probably due to the rigid and large conjugation system in the structure of phen.

Free phen shows longer photoluminescence lifetime (4.351 ns) and stronger emission intensity than those of the other organic ligands, which is probably due to the rigid and large conjugation system in the structure of phen.

elements.content: As shown in Figure S3 of the , complexes 1, 2, and 5 display similar weak emission bands at 466 (λex = 338 nm), 464 nm (λex = 340 nm), and 464 nm (λex = 330 nm), respectively (Figure S3, ). Complex 3 shows good blue photoluminescence property, and it exhibits intense emission with maxima at approximately 467 nm upon excitation at 310 nm. Due to the 3d10 valence electron configuration of Zn(II) and Cd(II) ions, the emission band of the Zn(II) and Cd(II) complexes may be assigned to the LLCT transition, admixing with the LMCT transition as previously reported.

Due to the 3d10 valence electron configuration of Zn(II) and Cd(II) ions, the emission band of the Zn(II) and Cd(II) complexes may be assigned to the LLCT transition, admixing with the LMCT transition as previously reported.

Similarly, due to the coordinated 2,2′-bpy in complex 5, the emission of complex 5 is stronger than those of complexes 1 and 2.

The enhancement of luminescence in the two complexes may be attributed to the ligation of the ligand to the metal center, which enhances the rigidity of the ligand and reduces the loss of energy through a radiationless pathway.

elements.content: The process of fluorescence decay for complexes 1–3 and 5 also follows a single exponential decay law, giving luminescence lifetimes of 4.759, 4.457, 1.538, and 1.190 ns, respectively (Figure S4, ). The fluorescence lifetimes of complexes 1 (4.759 ns) and 2 (4.457 ns) are much longer than those of the free ligands H3L (0.728 ns) and BPPA (1.545 ns), indicating the highly rigidified structures of complexes 1 and 2 in the solid matrices due to the ligation to metal(II) ions. Complexes 1 (4.759 ns) and 2 (4.457 ns) also show longer fluorescence lifetimes than complexes 3 (1.538 ns) and 5 (1.190 ns). As described above, complexes 1 and 2 are covalently connected rigidified 3D and 2D architectures, respectively. As for complexes 3 and 5, they are mononuclear Zn(II) and Cd(II) complexes, respectively. The fluorescence lifetimes of the complexes are in good accordance with their single-crystal structure analyses.

elements.content: As described above, among complexes 1–3 and 5, complexes 3 and 5 possess stronger emission intensities, whereas complexes 1 and 2 show longer photoluminescence lifetimes. The luminescence lifetime is not proportional to the emission intensity of the metal complex, and the detailed mechanism is under investigation.

elements.content: Based on H3L, five metal(II) complexes have been synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 features a 2-nodal (4, 5)-connected 3D LIBNIU net with a (3.42.5.6.7)(32.43.5.62.7.8) topology. Complex 2 exhibits a 2-nodal (3, 4)-connected 2D framework with a novel (4.7.8)(4.74.8) topology, in which the μ2-BPPA is self-penetrated into a cage of the 2D layer constructed by neighboring six Zn(II) ions and six L3–. Complexes 3–5 are mononuclear metal(II) complexes, in which complexes 3 and 4 are isostructural. Different π–π stacking interactions are observed in complexes 3–5. L3– or HL2– displays different coordination modes in the five complexes. Complexes 1–3 and 5 show different UV absorptions, emission spectra, and photoluminescence lifetimes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Based on H3L, five metal(II) complexes have been synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 features a 2-nodal (4, 5)-connected 3D LIBNIU net with a (3.42.5.6.7)(32.43.5.62.7.8) topology. Complex 2 exhibits a 2-nodal (3, 4)-connected 2D framework with a novel (4.7.8)(4.74.8) topology, in which the μ2-BPPA is self-penetrated into a cage of the 2D layer constructed by neighboring six Zn(II) ions and six L3-. Complexes 3-5 are mononuclear metal(II) complexes, in which complexes 3 and 4 are isostructural. Different π-π stacking interactions are observed in complexes 3-5. L3- or HL2- displays different coordination modes in the five complexes. Complexes 1-3 and 5 show different UV absorptions, emission spectra, and photoluminescence lifetimes.

cln_elements.content: As shown in Figure S3 of the , complexes 1, 2, and 5 display similar weak emission bands at 466 (λex = 338 nm), 464 nm (λex = 340 nm), and 464 nm (λex = 330 nm), respectively (Figure S3, ). Complex 3 shows good blue photoluminescence property, and it exhibits intense emission with maxima at approximately 467 nm upon excitation at 310 nm. Due to the 3d10 valence electron configuration of Zn(II) and Cd(II) ions, the emission band of the Zn(II) and Cd(II) complexes may be assigned to the LLCT transition, admixing with the LMCT transition as previously reported.
